intro: Tetrapterys crispa subsp. pseudotriopterys, commonly known as the creeping sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial herb with small, ovate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in sandy or well-drained soils and is often found in open, disturbed habitats. Its botanical characteristics make it an interesting species for ecological studies and native plant gardens.
